did.abstract: Astronomer, professor of astronomy at the University of Chicago, later at the University of Michigan. Biographical material, correspondence, topical files, teaching materials, research files, and photographs relating to professional interests, including his interest in photoelectric photometry leading to the discovery of interstellar polarization; also files relating to various observatories.

bioghist.p: William A. Hiltner was born in North Creek, Ohio on August 27, 1914. He received a B.S. in math and physics from the University of Toledo in 1937. Subsequently, he earned a M.S. degree in 1938 and a Ph.D. in astronomy in 1942 from the University of Michigan. In 1967 he was awarded an honorary degree from the University of Toledo. From 1942 through 1970, Hiltner was on the faculty at the University of Chicago and during parts of his tenure there was the director of Yerkes Observatory (1963-1966) and acting director of Cerro Tololo InterAmerican Observatory (1966-1967) in Chile. Hiltner's tenure at the University of Michigan began in 1970 when he was appointed chairman of the Department of Astronomy and director of University Observatories. He was chairman of the department until 1983 and retired from the University of Michigan in 1985.

The focus of Hiltner's research was work on photoelectric photometry which led to the discovery of interstellar polarization. Additionally, his work enabled the identification of a number of X-ray sources and provided the first evidence for a magnetic field pervading the Milky Way galaxy. To help with his ground breaking research, Hiltner designed and developed new instrumental techniques and applications. During his tenure at the University of Michigan, Hiltner was responsible for the establishment of the McGraw-Hill Observatory on Kitt Peak in Arizona which involved the moving of a 1.3-meter reflector from Dexter, Michigan to Arizona and the construction and implementation of a 2.4-meter telescope, which has now been named in his honor. During his lifetime, Hiltner produced more than 200 research papers, book chapters, and other scientific contributions (a partial bibliography may be found in the topical files under "Letters of Merit").

Hiltner was a member of the International Astronomical Union; the American Astronomical Society; the Astronomical Society of the Pacific; and, the Optical Society of America. He was also a founder and extremely active member of the Associated Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) which runs the National Optical Astronomy Observatories in Arizona and Chile.

scopecontent.p: The papers of William A. Hiltner cover his active role both in the Department of Astronomy at the University of Michigan and in the field of astronomy in general. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence and topical files. Also included are some teaching and research materials and files relating to his professional associations.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series dates from 1942 to 1991. Up until approximately 1967, the files were arranged alphabetically within chronological blocks of time. Beginning in 1967, the files were arranged in chronological order only. The letters concerns Hiltner's professional activities, his research and the research of colleagues.

The Topical Files series represent files established by Hiltner concerning individuals, places and events. The researcher should consult both these files and the correspondence series for material on any given topic.

scopecontent.p: The Associated Universities for Research in Astronomy (AURA) series includes some of the records generated by a search committee. While Hiltner was an active member of AURA, during 1976 and 1977 he also served as chairman of the search committee that was charged with finding a new director for the organization. The records in this series relate to the formation of the search committee, the nomination of candidates, the consideration of candidates, and the selection of a new director.

scopecontent.p: The University of Chicago series consist of a number of reports and research projects which Hiltner generated during his tenure at the University of Chicago. Included are research proposals made to the National Foundation of Science, annual reports of Yerkes Observatory and progress reports of a project for the United States Air Force titled "Development of an Electrographic Image Tube." This series, while incomplete, does show a sampling of Hiltner's interests and activities during his twenty-seven years at the University of Chicago.

scopecontent.p: Teaching Materials and Evaluations consists of syllabi and exams for various astronomy courses taught or supervised by Hiltner. A few lecture notes and annotated comments on handouts reflect Hiltner's active role in the teaching process. Furthermore, the exams and syllabi themselves indicate the astronomical issues and topics deemed important for basic knowledge and understanding of the field during this time period. Additionally, student evaluations from varying time periods indicate the overall popularity of Hiltner's courses.

Michigan, Dartmouth, MIT (MDM) Astronomy Consortium series consists of correspondence and technical papers representing agreements between astronomers at The University of Michigan, MIT and Dartmouth University to construct a new observatory at Kitt Peak, Arizona. The series documents many aspects of relocating Michigan's 1.3-meter telescope to the new McGraw-Hill Observatory, including design specifications and various funding requests. Correspondence and newspaper articles provide important background information for the project and photographs document the physical packing and moving of the reflector. Also included in the series are the papers documenting Hiltner's proposal to build a 2.4-meter telescope at Kitt Peak. This series shows the active role that Hiltner took in cooperating with other astronomers to build and maintain adequate sites and increasingly sophisticated equipment for research observations.

scopecontent.p: Research Materials represent a miscellaneous conglomeration of photographs and data sheets. One of the limitations of this series is its incomplete nature. The series is arranged by those astronomical bodies such as stars and nebula that could be identified from the materials. The remaining photographs and data sheets may be found under general headings. Of special interest are the data and correspondence Hiltner generated during his involvement in the global observations of Sco-X-1 during the late 1960s. This series shows the wide range of Hiltner's research interests. Clarification of some items in the research materials series may be found in the chronological correspondence and topical files series.

scopecontent.p: Biographical and Personal Materials is a small series containing a short biographical sketch of Hiltner and a bibliography of his published works. "Political Correspondence" gives a slight idea of Hiltner's political beliefs on the Vietnam War and civil liberties through limited correspondence with politicians.

Writings is a small series with Hiltner's dissertation being the most significant holding. "Articles and Reports" contains a small and random collection of journal articles, conference papers, and grant reports from the mid-1950s.

scopecontent.p: The Photographic Materials series contains primarily photographs of observatories during various phases of construction and operation. "Astronomical Charts" holds a small number of photographic mappings of stars and other celestial objects.
